newsitem.title: DUBAI: Japan's trade with Gulf falls slightly in H1.
newsitem.headline: Japan's trade with Gulf falls slightly in H1.

text.p: The value of trade between Japan and Gulf Arab states fell by one percent to $17.46 billion in the first half of 1996, official figures showed on Tuesday.
In yen terms, however, the value of trade climbed 14.5 percent due to a much stronger dollar in the period, Japan External Trade Organisation (JETRO) said.
The GCC comprises Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman and Qatar.
Japan's trade with GCC states make up 4.7 percent of its total world trade.
"The trade balance in favour of the GCC countries went up slightly by 0.4 percent to $10.85 billion from $10.80 billion in the first half of 1995," said JETRO.

Japan's exports to the Gulf fell 3.1 percent to $3.3 billion in the first half, the fourth consecutive decrease in the half yearly figures in dollar terms. Japan's imports from the Gulf declined 0.4 percent to $14.15 billion -- making up 8.2 percent of total Japanese imports.
The value of Japan's crude oil imports from Gulf Arab states climbed 0.6 percent to $10.53 billion, accounting for 68.9 percent of total Japanese crude oil imports.
